ld.headline: Fiscal Policy & Government Spending – Types, Components, Impacts

overview.title: Overview
items: Fiscal policy refers to government decisions on taxation, spending, and borrowing to influence economic growth, inflation, and employment levels.
Government spending, a key part of fiscal policy, includes expenditures on public goods and services, infrastructure, and social programs, impacting stability and growth.
Through fiscal policy, governments aim to achieve sustainable growth, reduce unemployment, and maintain price stability.

items.label: Expansionary Fiscal Policy:
items.text: Implemented to stimulate the economy by increasing government spending, cutting taxes, or both—used during recessions to boost demand and create jobs.

items.label: Contractionary Fiscal Policy:
items.text: Aimed at slowing an overheating economy, usually by reducing government spending or raising taxes to curb inflation.

items.label: Neutral Fiscal Policy:
items.text: Maintains a balanced budget where spending equals revenue, resulting in neither expansionary nor contractionary effects.

public.title: Public Goods and Services
items: Government spending provides essential services like education, healthcare, and public safety, promoting welfare and stability.
Investments in infrastructure such as roads, transport, and utilities improve efficiency and support long-term growth.

social.title: Social Programs
items: Expenditures on programs like unemployment benefits, social security, and welfare reduce inequality and support low-income households.
These programs act as automatic stabilizers, maintaining consumption during downturns and aiding recovery.

defense.title: Defense and National Security
items: A significant portion of government spending goes to defense and security, ensuring national protection and stability.
This spending supports military personnel, technology, and related industries, contributing to economic activity.

impact.title: Impact of Fiscal Policy on the Economy

growth.title: Economic Growth and Employment
items: Expansionary fiscal policy boosts demand and job creation, raising GDP growth.
Contractionary policy may slow growth and raise unemployment while controlling inflation.

inflation.title: Inflation Control
items: Governments may cut spending or raise taxes to cool demand during inflationary periods.
Balancing inflation prevents excessive price increases that erode purchasing power.

debt.title: Public Debt and Budget Deficits
items: When spending exceeds revenue, deficits arise, increasing public debt and limiting future fiscal flexibility.
Excessive debt raises interest costs and requires careful management to remain sustainable.

benefits.title: Benefits of Effective Fiscal Policy
items: Promotes Economic Stability: Well-managed fiscal policies stabilize growth and reduce volatility.
Improves Employment and Living Standards: Expansionary measures increase jobs and income.
Supports Income Redistribution: Social programs reduce inequality and support low-income groups.

limits.title: Limitations and Challenges of Fiscal Policy
items: Political Constraints: Policy decisions are often delayed or distorted by political agendas.
Lagging Effect: Fiscal measures take time to impact the economy, reducing short-term effectiveness.
Risk of Increased Public Debt: Persistent deficits limit flexibility and increase debt servicing costs.
